duck: gratitude definition: the state of being grateful.
Ungrateful (album), an album by American rock band Escape the Fate; it includes the song "Ungrateful".
"Gratitude" (song), by the Beastie Boys from the 1992 album Check Your Head
Gratitude (band), a defunct California rock band from the early 2000s

wiki.text:
Thank You}} Thanks}} with "merci", the French word for "thanks", written on it,
planted in front of a cross in the Normandy American Cemetery and Memorial]]
'Gratitude', 'thankfulness', 'gratefulness', or 'appreciation' is a feeling or
attitude in acknowledgment of a benefit that one has received or will receive.
The experience of gratitude has historically been a focus of several world
religions,<ref name="ReferenceB">Emmons, Robert A., and Cheryl A. Crumpler.
"Gratitude as a Human Strength: Appraising the Evidence." Journal of Social and
Clinical Psychology 19.1 (2000): 56-69. Print.</ref> and has been considered
extensively by moral philosophers such as Adam Smith.<ref>Smith, A. (1790/1976).
The Theory of Moral Sentiments (6th ed.). Indianapolis, IN: Liberty Classics.
(Original work published 1790).</ref> The systematic study of gratitude within
psychology only began around the year 2000, possibly because psychology has
traditionally been focused more on understanding distress rather than
understanding positive emotions. However, with the advent of the positive
psychology movement,<ref>Linley, P. A., Joseph, S., Harrington, S., & Wood, A.
M. (2006). [http://personalpages.manchester.ac.uk/staff/alex.wood/positive%20ps-
ychology,%20past%20present%20and%20possible%20future.pdf Positive psychology:
Past, present, and (possible) future.]The Journal of Positive Psychology, 1, 3-
16.</ref> gratitude has become a mainstream focus of psychological research.<ref
name="WoodPsychologist">Wood, A. M., Joseph, S., & Linley, P. A. (2007). [http:-
//personalpages.manchester.ac.uk/staff/alex.wood/gratitude%20psychologist.pdf
Gratitude: The parent of all virtues.] The Psychologist, 20, 18-21</ref> The
study of gratitude within psychology has focused on the understanding of the
short term experience of the emotion of gratitude (state gratitude), individual
differences in how frequently people feel gratitude (trait gratitude), and the
relationship between these two aspects.<ref name="WoodEmotion">Wood, A. M.,
Maltby, J., Stewart, N., Linley, P. A., & Joseph, S. (2008). [http://personalpa-
ges.manchester.ac.uk/staff/alex.wood/state%20and%20trait%20gratitude.pdf A social-
cognitive model of trait and state levels of gratitude].Emotion, 8, 281-
290.</ref><ref>McCullough, M. E., Tsang, J. & Emmons, R. A. (2004). Gratitude in
intermediate affective terrain: Links of grateful moods to individual
differences and daily emotional experience. [[Journal of Personality and Social
Psychology]], 86,295-309. [http://www.psy.miami.edu/faculty/mmccullough/gratitu-
de/Emmons_McCullough_2003_JPSP.pdf (electronic copy)]</ref>
wiki.title: gratitude
